absolutely no knowledge of the implementation of either the
This is perfect encapsulation—in a non-OO language. C programmers used to do this
kind of thing all the time. We would forward declare data structures and functions in
header files, and then implement them in
implementation files. Our users never had
access to the elements in those implementation files.
But then came OO in the form of C++—and the perfect encapsulation of C was broken.
The C++ compiler, for technical reasons,
needed the member variables of a class to be
declared in the header file of that class. So our
